word.entryDescription: a mechanism for determining the location of an object
word.entryExample: Its onboard satellite positioning system makes sure that the car's engine and braking systems slow down.

word.entryDescription: the good thing
word.entryExample: Try to find positives in any situation.

word.entryDescription: something you own or have with you
word.entryExample: There is not a lot of space for possessions on a houseboat.

word.entryDescription: a position of employment, a job
word.entryExample: Jim is having an interview for the post of course assistant at a local language school.

word.entryDescription: a place where you can buy stamps and send letters
word.entryExample: Do you know where the post office is?

word.entryDescription: a card with a picture on one side, and a place to write on the other side which you send to someone by post
word.entryExample: I've got a postcard from my friends in America.

word.entryDescription: a series of letters and numbers used as part of an address when you send something by post
word.entryExample: You can insert your postcode to find the recycling centre closest to you.

word.entryDescription: a large paper picture or notice
word.entryExample: I love that poster of Lionel Messi – where did you get that?

word.entryDescription: the position your body is in when you are sitting or standing
word.entryExample: Back pains can be the result of bad posture.

word.entryDescription: a deep round container with an open top
word.entryExample: You can paint some birds on the pot to make it more beautiful.

word.entryDescription: a round vegetable with thin skin and hard white flesh, which grows underground
word.entryExample: We had sausages and potatoes for dinner.

word.entryDescription: objects made from clay and then baked
word.entryExample: People made pots there long ago and pottery was an important business in this area.

word.entryDescription: to beat strongly and quickly
word.entryExample: Suddenly the moment I'd been dreading arrived and my heart was pounding.

word.entryDescription: to make a liquid flow out of a container by raising one side
word.entryExample: Please, pour tea for everyone.

word.entryDescription: having a strong effect on someone's feelings or opinions
word.entryExample: The classical jazz concert I saw at Carnegie Hall was more powerful than the one I saw last year.

word.entryDescription: relating to real situations rather than ideas
word.entryExample: She was a practical woman with a lot of common sense.

word.entryDescription: doing something regularly in order to improve your skill
word.entryExample: Although it’s difficult at first, you get better with practice.

word.entryDescription: to do something regularly in order to become better at it
word.entryExample: Did you practise your goal shots yet?

word.entryDescription: valuable and important and not to be wasted
word.entryExample: Campaigners are asking for radical changes in the trade of soya in order to protect our precious rainforests.

word.entryDescription: an animal that hunts other animals for food
word.entryExample: Predators eat other animals.

word.entryDescription: easy to guess what will happen
word.entryExample: The ending was the most predictable of all his films.

word.entryDescription: a statement about what you think is going to happen; or making such a statement
word.entryExample: Were your predictions correct?

word.entryDescription: to like or choose one thing rather than something else
word.entryExample: Louise would prefer to tidy her bedroom than do her maths homework.

word.entryDescription: having a baby developing inside the body
word.entryExample: Barbara is pregnant and expecting a baby in four months.

word.entryDescription: to heat an oven to a necessary temperature before you put food in it to cook
word.entryExample: First, preheat the oven.

word.entryDescription: connected with the time in history before anything was written down
word.entryExample: Humans learned to cook with fire in prehistoric times.

word.entryDescription: to get something ready for the future
word.entryExample: Many of us have forgotten how much fun it can be to prepare a family dinner.

word.entryDescription: a piece of paper on which a doctor writes down the medicine or treatment needed
word.entryExample: The doctor gave Mr. Stone a prescription for some allergy medicine.

word.entryDescription: something you give to somebody, often on a special occasion such as a birthday
word.entryExample: Sally's got lots of birthday presents.

word.entryDescription: (of food) to prevent something from decaying by treating it in a particular way
word.entryExample: Fresh food does not stay fresh for a very long time, so it must be preserved or cooked.

word.entryDescription: to push a button, switch, key, etc on a machine, device, etc
word.entryExample: If they saw a happy face, they had to press the ‘yes’ key.

word.entryDescription: the force produced by something as it pushes on something else
word.entryExample: Both 'climate' and 'weather' relate to temperature, humidity, rainfall, wind and atmospheric pressure and particles.

word.entryDescription: admired and respected because of being important and one of the best
word.entryExample: This is one one of the most prestigious universities in our country.

word.entryDescription: good-looking, especially a girl or young woman
word.entryExample: This dress is very pretty.

word.entryDescription: to stop something from happening
word.entryExample: I hope that in the future people will do more to prevent climate change.

word.entryDescription: something that can be stopped from happening
word.entryExample: The epidemic is preventable and is being prevented in many industrialised countries.

word.entryDescription: an animal that is hunted by another animal for food
word.entryExample: Insects are prey for swallows.

word.entryDescription: the amount of money for which something is sold
word.entryExample: What's the price of success?

word.entryDescription: the son of a king, queen or prince
word.entryExample: The prince looked for Cinderella.

word.entryDescription: an idea or a theory that something is based on
word.entryExample: I won't do this. It's against my principles.

word.entryDescription: a copy of a painting that is produced by taking a photograph of it and printing it onto paper
word.entryExample: The first picture is a print.

word.entryDescription: to print a file on paper
word.entryExample: I couldn't print out my report as there was no paper left.

word.entryDescription: suitable to be printed
word.entryExample: His comments were not printable.

word.entryDescription: produced on paper, using a machine which puts ink onto the surface
word.entryExample: We sell the advertising on the printed material.

word.entryDescription: a device which is connected to a computer and can make a printed record of computer information
word.entryExample: I have a computer and a printer, of course, so I can send and print out emails.

word.entryDescription: the cable that carries data between a computer and a printer
word.entryExample: Have you checked the printer cable?

word.entryDescription: a place where criminals are kept
word.entryExample: The murderer was sent to prison for 30 years for killing the victim.

word.entryDescription: in a pure or natural undamaged state
word.entryExample: There's not much pristine forest left in Europe.

word.entryDescription: the state of being free from the presence or attention of other people
word.entryExample: You don't get much privacy when you live in a block of flats.

word.entryDescription: belonging to or for use by one person or group, not for everyone
word.entryExample: The Thunderbird capsule will carry private astronauts into space.
